entry.content:
Revised Closure Order

Incident: Blacktail Fire Wildfire
Released: 30 min. ago

HELENA-LEWIS AND CLARK NATIONAL FOREST

Belt Creek-White Sulphur Springs Ranger District White Sulphur Springs, Montana

Order No. 01-15-14-17-56 EMERGENCY ORDER

National Forest System Road, Trails and Area Closure

Pursuant to 36 CFR 261.50(a) and (b), when provided by an order, the following acts are prohibited on the Belt Creek-White Sulphur Springs Ranger District, Helena-Lewis and Clark National Forest:

Being on the road. (36 CFR 261.54e) Being on the trail. (36 CFR 261.55a)

Going into or being upon an area – see map. (36 CFR 261.52e)

This area closure boundary includes all National Forest Service lands, roads and trails, including those listed below on the Belt Creek-White Sulphur Springs Ranger District (map). The area closure boundary will run from Buzzard Creek on the north to the Divide of Blacktail Creek and Middle Fork Big Elk Creek, then south to Lebo Fork and then due east three miles to the Forest Boundary at O’Hearn Creek, as shown on the attached map.

Closed roads include:

· National Forest System Road 654 in Wheatland County, T5N, R11E

Closed trails include:

· #630 – portion south of Buzzard Creek

· #630A – portion north of Lebo Fork of Big Elk Creek

· #640 – From Section 1 on the west side to junction of Trail 654 Elk Lake

· #654 – Elk Lake Trail

These restrictions are in support of the Blacktail Fire operations in the Crazy Mountains and will remain in effect until December 1st or until rescinded.

Pursuant to 36 CFR 261.50(e), the following persons are exempt from this Order:

1. Persons with a permit specifically authorizing the otherwise prohibited act or omission.
2. Any Federal, State, or Local Law Enforcement Officer or member of an organized rescue or firefighting force in the performance of an official duty.


These prohibitions are in addition to the general prohibitions in 36 CFR 261, Subpart A and a copy of this order will posted according to 36 CFR 261.51.

Executed in Helena, Montana, this _19th day of September 2017.

/s/William Avey

WILLIAM AVEY

Forest Supervisor

Violation of these prohibitions is punishable by a fine of not more than $5,000 for an individual or $10,000 for an organization, imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or both. (16 U.S.C. 551 and 18 U.S.C. 3559 and 3571).

entry.content:
Blacktail Fire Update 9-18-17

Incident: Blacktail Fire Wildfire
Released: 18 min. ago

Fire Information Line: (406) 333-1544

Follow Fire Information on Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5606/

Email: blacktailfire2017@gmail.com

Important – Drones are prohibited in the fires vicinity & have potential to shut down all operations.

Start date: September 10, 2017
Location: Southwest of Two Dot, Montana
Cause: Lightning Size: 5,351
Containment: 25%
Total Personnel: 101 personnel

Yesterday’s Operations: Crews worked from pre-identified drop points, or staging areas, assessing conditions and determining where they may have access to the fire area. Because of the rain and snow received over the previous few days, entry into much of the fire area has been very difficult. Members of the Incident Command Team were able to fly over the fire yesterday to further assess the status of the fire and area conditions. The Incident Command Team and agency administrators held two community meetings in Melville and Two Dot.

Planned Operations: Due to current conditions and expected weather, a substantial number of the fire’s resources will be demobilized today and available for other incidents. The remaining personnel will patrol and monitor the fire. Another reconnaissance flight is scheduled for today.

Closures: Helena-Lewis and Clark National Forest closures for the fire area (Order No. 01-15-07-17-45 and Order No. 01-15-07-17-47) were rescinded Saturday morning. Listings of the roads and trails now open are posted on the fire’s Inciweb closure link. However, an area closure is still in effect for within the fire’s perimeter.

Resources Assigned: Cain’s Nevada Interagency Type III Incident Management Team is still assigned to the fire. The team will transfer operational control of the fire to the local unit on Wednesday morning. One dozer, one grader, an engine, and a Type 3 helicopter are currently assigned to the incident.

Weather: The forecast calls for partly sunny skies on Monday, with a cold front approaching late in the afternoon. The front is expected to bring gusty winds and a chance of showers. A mix of rain and snow is possible Monday night into Tuesday.

Fire History: The fire was reported at approximately 3:00 pm on Sunday, September 10. Nine smokejumpers initial attacked the fire and were assisted by local resources, including volunteer fire departments from Two Dot, Melville, Wheatland, and Sweet Grass counties. Firefighting efforts were assisted with two helicopters and single engine air tankers dropping retardant as needed. Suppression efforts were hampered by high winds coupled with steep rocky terrain. This fire includes both Federal and Private Lands in Meagher, Wheatland, and Sweet Grass Counties.

Planned Operations: Crews will work from pre-identified staging areas today, seeing what snow levels remain and where they have best access to the fire area. Most of the resources will be working on or near...
entry.content:
Blacktail Fire Update 9-17-17

Incident: Blacktail Fire Wildfire
Released: 12 min. ago

Fire Information Line: (406) 333-1544

Follow Fire Information: Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5606/

Email: blacktailfire2017@gmail.com

Important – Drones are prohibited in the fires vicinity & have potential to shut down all operations.

Start date: September 10, 2017
Location: Southwest of Two Dot, Montana
Cause: Lightning
Size: 5,351
Containment: 20%
Total Personnel: 104 personnel

Yesterday’s Operations: Fire activity was restricted yesterday due to the weather. Field personnel assessing conditions in the fire area noted 8-12” of snow. As a result, most of the fire resources were staged at the Incident Command Post in Two Dot, checking gear and performing maintenance on equipment in preparation for continued operations under more favorable conditions.

Planned Operations: Crews will work from pre-identified staging areas today, seeing what snow levels remain and where they have best access to the fire area. Most of the resources will be working on or near Blacktail Road, east of the fire, where snow had melted away late yesterday afternoon. Firefighters will also hike into the north end of the fire, looking for areas that may still be retaining heat. All personnel traveling in the fire area will work carefully to limit resource damage on muddy roads and trails.

Community Meetings: Two community meetings are planned for today, Sunday, September 17. Locations and times include Bill’s Place in Melville at 2:00 pm and the Two Dot Fire Hall at 5:30 pm. All public are welcome to attend.

Closures: Helena-Lewis and Clark National Forest closures for the fire area (Order No. 01-15-07-17-45 and Order No. 01-15-07-17-47) were rescinded Saturday morning. Listings of the areas now open are posted on the fire’s Inciweb site at https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/article/5606/41203/. Also, per notification from the Gallatin National Forest, Lodgepole Trail #844 southwest of the Blacktail Fire area is now open. Anyone traveling near the fire area should be cautious of falling trees and fire equipment traveling on the roads.

Resources Assigned: Cain’s Nevada Interagency Type III Incident Management Team is still assigned to the fire. Seven engines, one water tender, one dozer, one grader, two 20-person hand crews, and one Type 3 helicopter are also assigned to the incident.

Weather: The forecast calls for dry conditions today through Monday afternoon. Westerly winds will increase overnight tonight and be gusty at times through Tuesday as a cold front approaches. There is a good chance for wetting rain on Monday night and Tuesday.

Fire History: The fire was reported at approximately 3:00 pm on Sunday, September 10. Nine smokejumpers initial attacked the fire and were assisted by local resources, including volunteer fire departments from Two Dot, Melville, Wheatland, and Sweet Grass counties. Firefighting efforts were assisted with two helicopters and single engine air tankers dropping retardant as needed. Suppression efforts were hampered by high winds coupled with steep rocky terrain. This fire includes both Federal and Private Lands in Meagher, Wheatland, and Sweet Grass Counties.

entry.title: Closures Lifted
entry.summary: The Helena-Lewis and Clark National Forest Closure for the Blacktail fire area (Order No. 01-15-07-17-47) was rescinded Saturday morning, September 16. The following trails are now open: #636 – Loco Mountain Trail; #640 – Lebo Fork to Elk Lake Trail; #630A, 630 – Lebo Fork to North Fork to Bear Spring Trail; #634 – Cinnamon Creek Trail to the junction with Trail 636. Additionally, all unnumbered, non-system roads on the National Forest System lands within the area closure are now open, including: #9285 – Bear Spring Road; #654 – Lebo Fork Road; Middle Fork of American Fork Road

entry.content:
Blacktail Fire Update 9-16-17

Incident: Blacktail Fire Wildfire
Released: 4 hrs. ago

Fire Information Line: (406) 333-1544

Follow Fire Information: Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5606/

Email: blacktailfire2017@gmail.com

Important – Drones are prohibited in the fires vicinity & have potential to shut down all operations.

Start date: September 10, 2017

Location: Southwest of Two Dot, Montana

Cause: Lightning

Size: 5,351

Containment: 20%

Total Personnel: 100 personnel

Yesterday’s Operations: Crews continued to hold and improve existing containment lines. They also scouted locations to put in new containment lines when weather allows.

Planned Operations: Fire activity will be limited today due to the weather. The rain and snow are making access roads into the fire area muddy and slippery. Most of the fire resources will stage at the Incident Command Post in Two Dot today, checking gear and performing maintenance on equipment in preparation for continued operations on Sunday when drier conditions are forecast. Any personnel traveling in the fire area will work carefully to limit resource damage on muddy roads and trails, restricting driving off roads when possible.

Closures: A closure for the fire area was rescinded this morning. The following trails are now open: #636 – Loco Mountain Trail; #640 – Lebo Fork to Elk Lake Trail; #630A, 630 – Lebo Fork to North Fork to Bear Spring Trail; #634 – Cinnamon Creek Trail to the junction with Trail 636. Additionally, all unnumbered, non-system roads on the National Forest System lands within the area closure are now open, including: #9285 – Bear Spring Road; #654 – Lebo Fork Road; Middle Fork of American Fork Road.

Resources Assigned: Cain’s Nevada Interagency Type III Incident Management Team assumed command of the Blacktail fire on September 12, 2017. This fire includes both Federal and Private Lands in Meagher, Wheatland and Sweet Grass Counties. Seven engines, two water tenders, two dozers, one grader, nine smoke jumpers, one 20-person hand crew, and one Type 3 helicopter are currently assigned to the fire.

Weather: A mix of rain and snow is expected to continue impact the fire area again today, tapering off in the afternoon. Warmer and drier conditions are expected for Sunday and Monday, but another round of precipitation is expected for midweek.

Fire History: The fire was reported at approximately 1500 hours on Sunday, September 10. Nine smokejumpers initial attacked the fire and were assisted by local resources, including volunteer fire departments from Two Dot, Melville, Wheatland, and Sweet Grass counties. Firefighting efforts were assisted with two helicopters and single engine air tankers dropping retardant as needed. Suppression efforts were hampered by high winds coupled with steep rocky terrain.

entry.content:
Blacktail Fire Update 9-15-2017

Incident: Blacktail Fire Wildfire
Released: 1 day ago

Fire Information Line: (406) 333-1544

Follow Fire Information: Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5606/

Email: blacktailfire2017@gmail.com

Important – Drones are prohibited in the fires vicinity & have potential to shut down all operations.

Start date: September 10, 2017

Location: Southwest of Two Dot, Montana

Cause: Lightning

Size: 5,351

Containment: 15%

Total Personnel: 100 personnel

Resources Assigned: Cain’s Nevada Interagency Type III Incident Management Team assumed command of the Blacktail fire on September 12, 2017. This fire includes both Federal and Private Lands in Meagher, Wheatland and Sweet Grass Counties. Numerous engines are assigned, as well as, one Type 2 Initial Attack 20 - person hand crew as well as numerous pieces of heavy equipment. Firefighters efforts are supported by 2 Type 3 (Light) helicopters and 1 Type 2 (Medium) helicopter.

Fire History: The fire was reported at approximately 1500 hours on Sunday September 10, 2017. Nine smokejumpers initial attacked the fire and were assisted by local resources including volunteer fire departments from Two Dot, Melville, Wheatland and Sweet Grass counties. Firefighting efforts were assisted with two helicopter and single engine air tankers dropping retardant as needed. Suppression efforts have been hampered by high winds coupled with steep rocky terrain. Active fire behavior has been reported on the fire into the early morning hours.

Yesterday’s Operations: Crews were able to take advantage of the rainy conditions to put fireline in along the north fire perimeter. Additional crews were able to continue improving existing contingency lines along the east and south fire perimeters utilizing both heavy equipment as well as engines.

Planned Operations: Firefighters are continuing to improve identified contingency lines and hold and improve existing containment lines along the northern perimeter of the fire. Along the south firefighters will be improving existing contingency lines as well as construction of fireline to minimize fire spread to the south toward O’Hearn Creek.

Closures: A new closure has been put into place for the fire area. The boundary will run on the north side along the proclaimed Forest Boundary on the north side of the Crazy Mountains where Trail 636 intersects the Forest Boundary and then east and south following the Forest Boundary to the boundary of the Belt Creek-White Sulphur Springs Ranger District and the Yellowstone Ranger District. The closure area then traverses west-northwesterly on the boundary between the ranger districts to the junction of Trail 636, and then northward on and including Trail 636 to the point of origination on the north boundary. For more details on the closure and/or a closure map please check inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5606/#

Weather: Showers will continue in the fire area today and tomorrow. Up to an inch of precipitation is expected. This is expected to significantly hamper fire activity, although it is not expected to extinguish the fire completely.

###

entry.content:
Blacktail Fire Update

Incident: Blacktail Fire Wildfire
Released: 35 min. ago

Fire Information Line: (406) 333-1544

Follow Fire Information: Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5606/

Email: blacktailfire2017@gmail.com

Important – Drones are prohibited in the fires vicinity & have potential to shut down all operations.

Start date: September 10, 2017

Location: Southeast of Two Dot, Montana

Cause: Lightning

Size: 4000-5000

Total Personnel: 100 personnel

Resources Assigned: Cain’s Nevada Interagency Type III Incident Management Team assumed command of the Blacktail fire yesterday. This fire includes both Federal and Private Lands in Meagher, Wheatland and Sweet Grass Counties.

Fire History: The fire was reported at approximately 1500 hours on Sunday September 10, 2017. Nine smokejumpers initial attacked the fire and were assisted by local resources including volunteer fire departments from Two Dot, Melville, Wheatland and Sweet Grass counties. Firefighting efforts were assisted with two helicopter and single engine air tankers dropping retardant as needed. Suppression efforts have been hampered by high winds coupled with steep rocky terrain. Active fire behavior has been reported on the fire into the early morning hours.

Planned Operations: Cain’s Nevada Interagency Type III Incident Management Team took command of the fire late Tuesday night. Firefighters are working on improving identified contingency lines and scouting for opportunities to build control lines on the southern flank. In addition firefighters will be scouting for opportunities to use strategic firing operations to prevent further fire spread onto private lands.

Closures: Forest Road 654 as well as Forest Trails 630A and 640 are closed at this time. For more details on the closure please check inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5606/#

Weather: Isolated thunderstorms are expected this evening, mostly cloudy with a chance of scattered showers. Temperatures will be in the mid-70’s today and relative humidity’s will be in the upper 20’s. Rain showers are expected throughout the fire area much of Thursday. While these showers are not expected to put out the fire they will assist the firefighters in building fireline.

###

entry.content:
Closure Order

Incident: Blacktail Fire Wildfire
Released: 28 min. ago

HELENA- LEWIS AND CLARK NATIONAL FOREST

Belt Creek-White Sulphur Springs Ranger District White Sulphur Springs, Montana

Order No. 01-15-07-17-45

EMERGENCY ORDER

National Forest System Roads and Trails

Pursuant to 36 CFR 261.50(b), when provided by an order, the following are prohibited on the Belt Creek­ White Sulphur Springs Ranger District:

Being on the road. (36 CFR 261.54e) Being on the trail. (36 CFR 261.55a)

These restrictions apply to the National Forest System Roads and Trails on the Belt Creek-White Sulphur Springs Ranger District, as described below (see Blacktail Fire Closures Map):

National Forest System Road 654 in Wheatland County, T5N, R11E,

National Forest System Trail 640 and 630-A in the Big Elk Creek drainage in Wheatland and Meagher Counties.

These restrictions are in support of the Blacktail Fire and will remain in effect until rescinded. Pursuant to 36 CFR 261.50(e), the following persons are exempt from this Order:

  1. Persons with a permit specifically authorizing the otherwise prohibited act or omission.

  2. Any Federal, State or Local Law Enforcement Officer or member of an organized rescue or fire fighting force in the performance of an official duty.

These prohibitions are in addition to the general prohibitions in 36 CFR Part 261, Subpart A and a copy of this order will be posted according to 36 CFR 261.51.

Executed in Helena, Montana, this 11th day of September, 2017.


WILLIAM AVEY
Forest Supervisor

Violation of these prohibitions is punishable by a fine of not more than $5,000 for an individual or $10,000 for an organization, imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or both. (16 U.S.C. 551 and 18 U.S.C. 3559 and 3571).
